Leptotrombidium deliense is of medical importance as it is the primary vector for the transmission of scrub typhus, a serious infectious disease caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi. The larvae of this mite, commonly referred to as chiggers, feed on the skin of humans and other vertebrates, injecting a digestive enzyme that can cause intense itching and inflammation.

The adult mites are small, measuring around 0.5-0.8 millimeters in length, and have a distinctive red or orange coloration. They live in moist, grassy environments and feed on the eggs and larvae of other small arthropods. The larvae of L. deliense are the only life stage that parasitizes vertebrates, including humans, and are responsible for the transmission of scrub typhus.

Effective control and prevention of scrub typhus outbreaks involve a combination of measures, including the use of insect repellents, avoidance of infested areas, and prompt medical treatment of suspected cases.
